awd_titl_txt: LTREB Renewal: Climatic drivers of temporal and spatial dynamics of a focal herbivore
awd_abstract_narration:
The Earth's climate has changed continually over 4 billion years. The recent increased pace and direction of this change challenge the nation's welfare, the economics of agriculture, and the management of essential resources. This project provides a unique opportunity to identify the mechanisms by which short-term climatic effects cause long-term population changes, affect spatial exchanges between local populations, and result in the extinction of some populations. The project focuses on a common herbivore, the wooly-bear caterpillar, and results have the potential to inform conservation and management of beneficial as well as pest herbivores. More importantly, the project will be integrated into high school curricula by involving students and teachers in monitoring caterpillar abundances. Undergraduate students from groups under-represented in science and graduate students will also receive training in the practice of science through their participation in the project
 
The wooly-bear moth, Platyprepia virginalis, is a primary herbivore on lupines in California. The investigators have accumulated up to 30 years of abundance data for this species and for important drivers of its population dynamics, including host plants, other herbivores, predators, parasitoids, movement, and climatic conditions. The project will initiate short-term experiments to identify mechanisms that causally link climatic factors to observed patterns of abundance and distribution across habitats.  These will evaluate top-down effects of climate on predators, bottom-up climate effects through a facilitative interaction involving a second herbivore species, and the effects of flooding and litter accumulation on caterpillar vital rates. Statistical analyses and mathematical models will test inferences from these experiments, evaluating whether the hypothesized mechanisms cause inter-annual fluctuations in abundance and changing spatial dynamics including local extinctions.  The project's combination of manipulative experiments with model development and analyses of long-term demographic data is rare. It will provide a well-documented example of source-sink dynamics, an ecological phenomenon for which data remain scarce, and is likely to become a classic example of the consequences of climate change for population dynamics.

por.por_cntn:
Several recent reports have described significant declines in insect populations across the globe, the so-called insect Armageddon in the popular press. These reports are alarming because insects are close to the base of most terrestrial food webs and provide valuable ecosystem services such as pollinating our crops, providing natural pest control, recycling our wastes, and many others. In order to evaluate the evidence that these declines have occurred we need careful, replicated, systematic surveys of insect populations that span sufficient time periods so that any possible declines associated with climate change can be detected. Unfortunately, relatively few long-term censuses of insect populations exist over appropriate time scales. In addition to census data that document potential declines, we need to know what factors have changed that are responsible for driving insect declines so as to be able to predict and possibly mitigate insect population dynamics.

We have collected survey data for populations of caterpillars of Arctia virginalis for the past 38 years. Our data clearly show that population sizes were strongly affected by annual precipitation. Wet years were followed by high numbers of caterpillars and droughts were followed by lower numbers. A similar pattern was observed by looking at different sites across the landscape - wetter sites had more caterpillars than drier sites. Populations at drier sites went locally extinct following droughts but were recolonized by moths from wetter sites during wet years. The rules governing population regulation also changed over the past four decades. Before 2000, populations responded relatively quickly to density, decreasing when crowded and increasing when sparse to produce short-term cycles. Following approximately 2004, population responses were more delayed and more persistent so that increases and decreases lasted for several years. This change also corresponded to more pronounced climatic extremes - wetter wet years and drier and longer droughts.

Understanding the effects of climate on insect populations requires that we gain a working knowledge about the factors that do and do not drive these populations. As mentioned above, we found that precipitation was an important driver of caterpillar numbers. Precipitation can directly benefit small caterpillars that are vulnerable to desiccation. In addition, rainy winters cause higher quality host plants for caterpillars. This host plant effect was relatively weak and the absolute quantity of food never appeared to become limiting. Precipitation also acted indirectly to reduce rates of mortality caused by predation by ants. Caterpillars remained active during winter months at lower temperatures associated with rainy weather than do their predators. The denser litter layer caused by more precipitation reduced the effectiveness of ant predators at finding and killing caterpillars. We found no evidence that parasitoids drove caterpillar populations even though rates of parasitism were often high. A recently discovered virus may be an important driver although more work is required to evaluate this possibility.

These results have several important implications. First, they provide clear evidence that climate is a major driver of population dynamics of this insect species. Second, by understanding how climate affects populations, we can predict how and when populations are likely to decline or likely to boom. Third, this detailed understanding of the drivers of populations provides us with potential tools to mitigate the negative effects of climate change if we find it desirable to do so.
